document.heading: Office of Employee Appeals Attorney Fees Clarification Amendment Act of 2002

history.narrative: Law 14-166, the “Office of Employee Appeals Attorney Fees Clarification Amendment Act of 2002”, was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 14-29, which was referred to the Committee on Government Operations. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on March 5, 2002, and April 9, 2002, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on April 30, 2002, it was assigned Act No. 14-355 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 14-166 became effective on June 28, 2002.

AN ACT IN THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA To amend the District of Columbia Government Comprehensive Merit Personnel Act of 1978 to authorize the Hearing Examiner or the Arbitrator to require payment by the agency of reasonable attorney fees to be applied retroactively, and provide that this provision expires one year after its effective date. BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Office of Employee Appeals Attorney Fees Clarification Amendment Act of 2002 Sec. 2. Section 607 of the District of Columbia Government Comprehensive Merit Personnel Act of 1978, effective May 15, 1990 (D.C. Law 8-127; D.C. Official Code § 1- 606.08 is amended as follows 1) Designate the existing text subsection (a 2) Add a new subsection (b) to read as follows b)(1) The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall apply retroactively to those who prevailed, and applied to the Office of Employee Appeals for such payment between September 15, 1988 and May 15, 1990 2) This subsection shall expire one year after its effective date Sec. 3.
